dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of a large, impressive-looking building  on the corner of a busy, New York business  street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dignified brass plate sign on the  side of the building, reading: UNION

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lower portion of high bronze doors,  one side of which is partly opened.  Sitting in front of the closed side  is a uniformed officer, greeting, ad  lib, the various employees as they enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of a cover being yanked off an adding  machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A telephone operator, busily plugging  in wires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning . . . Union National Bank  . . . Just a minuteВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 6. INT. ENTRANCE ROOM TO VAULTS - MED.  SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the inside of a massive vault door,  made impressive by the shining, finely  cut steel bolts and the many other intricate-looking  instruments which adorn it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS UP to a clock overhead which  registers 9:03.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of young men, paying tellers,  are impatiently watching a teller struggle  with the lock that will admit them to  the vault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, come on, Oscar, what are we  waiting for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Can't you find it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, if it had lipstick on it, he'd  find it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all laugh, as Oscar finds the combination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA MOVES WITH THEM as they pass  through the first portal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine o'clock and all is lousy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I spend half of my life waiting  for these time clocks to open. Say,  where's Matt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably upstairs thinking up that daily  joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That guy kills me with his wisecracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, when he comes in, let's put on  a frozen face. Let's not smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PICKS UP Matt Brown, the chief  teller, as he strides briskly in and  begins turning the combination dial  to the main vault. He is about twenty-six,  a clean-looking, personable youngster.  Several of the tellers are standing  close to him, looking on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt begins to work the combination  of the main lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, did you boys ever hear the story  of the pawnbroker with the glass eye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Matt, what is the story about the  pawnbroker with the glass eye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he continues to fiddle with the  lock)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll tell you. A fellow went into  this shop to pawn his watch. The pawnbroker  said, "I'll give you $50 for it, if  you can tell me which is my glass eye."  The fellow said, "All right, I'll do  that. It's the right one." The pawnbroker  said, "That's correct. But how did you  know it was the right one?" The fellow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: said, "well, it's got more sympathy  than the other one."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns, expecting their laugh, but  is confronted by stone faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sympathy! You know, the right one had  more sympathy than the other one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Can't you get this  thing open?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt stares in disbelief, then gets  the joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This cracks them all up, as a uniformed  officer, who has been standing by, works  a lever attached to the floor, which  lowers a section of the floor, directly  in front of the vault. This permits  the vault door, which is sunk below  the floor level, to swing open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love your jokes, Matt! They're so  entertaining! A very funny man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt opens the inside door, made up  of perpendicular steel bars. The tellers  scurry into the cavernous-looking interior.  Someone snaps on a light. CAMERA TRUCKS  UP TO VAULT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The back walls of the vault are lined  with steel cabinets divided into many  small compartments. On one side is a  wall safe which is also opened by a  combination and which contains the surplus  cash carried by the bank. Matt is in  charge of this. All around the room  are numerous hand trucks - one for every  teller. These trucks contain the cash  in the charge of the individual tellers.  While the tellers in the b.g. obtain  their keys and open the drawers of their  trucks, Matt examines the time clock  which is attached to the inside of the  vault door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the door, as Matt enters and goes  directly to the burglar alarm box to  the left of the doorway. He leans over  to throw off the burglar alarm switch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The handle of the switch points in the  direction of a sign reading ON. Matt's  hand comes into the scene and throws  the switch up toward a sign reading  OFF. This is done with no comment, it  being a routine matter with Matt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, white collars. The day's started!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the tellers file out with their trucks.  Before they do, however, each one signs  the cashbook. One or two exit silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As one of the tellers comes into scene.  Matt examines the cashbook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're carrying too much money on you,  Hank. You better turn some in tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, the last man, comes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say Matt, I'll have to have some money  for those Manville payrolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was more than that last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands Charlie four stacks of bills.  As Charlie is signing the cash book,  Matt speaks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, do me a favor, will you Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten bucks? Say, if I had ten bucks,  I'd quit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie starts out. Matt follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13. OUTSIDE OF VAULT - MED. CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Charlie comes out, followed by Matt.  CAMERA TRUCKS ALONG WITH THEM as they  walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pay it back to you Saturday - on  the level I will. Give a guy a break,  will you? I've got to get it back in  my account. If Helen ever finds out  that IВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, I can't give you anything but  love . . .[2]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14. INT. MAIN FLOOR OF BANK - BACKSTAGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA TRUCKS with them as Charlie pushes  his truck forward and Matt walks alongside  of him. En route, CAMERA TAKES IN ATMOSPHERIC  SHOTS of the general activity backstage  of the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Male and female clerks stand around  at various angles, checking away at  adding machines. Several are assisted  by someone who calls off figures to  them as they record it on machines.  We hear these figures read in a monotone  as we pass them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt is still trying to pry the ten  dollars loose from Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now listen Charlie. I'll give you an  I.O.U. I'll give you a note, I'll pay  your mortgage, it's a matter of life  and deathВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ad-lib conversations from the other  clerks distract his attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be yours if you don't kick in  with that ten bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say pal, did you ever hear of a Depression?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie arrives at his cage. CAMERA  STOPS with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come over and see us sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA CONTINUES TO FOLLOW Matt as he  continues on to his cage, muttering  half to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not asking you to pay off the Depression.  I'm only asking you for ten bucks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another teller is busy in the cage next  to him. Matt addresses him, referring  to Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That mug reminds me of a guy with his  second dollar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, what did he do with his first  one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA PICKS UP Helen as she crosses  the main floor of the bank, reaches  Matt's teller window and pushes it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans over, and she gives him a quick  kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, look out, somebody's likely to  see us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She quickly kisses him again, crosses  back, and takes the grand stairs up  to the outer office of the bank president  as Matt watches with a grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16. INT. MAIN FLOOR OF BANK - FULL SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then, a group of five or six important-looking  men enter scene on the way to the conference  room. One of the men looks towards Helen's  desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Helen and a secretary standing next  to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other clerks and tellers, noticing  the newcomers as they file past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And blowing no good for the old man,  either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they doing here? There's no  board meeting today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By this time, the important group of  men have reached Helen, and are passing  her by, with perfunctory nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the most important of the important-looking  men; to Helen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he comes in, tell him we're waiting  for him in the board room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And tell him not to delay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group of men file through the board  room door, and out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like trouble for your boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Takes more than two tons of directors  to make trouble for my boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking in all of room. The directors  are all here, and some sit around a  long, narrow mahogany table. Clark,  the sour-faced old

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: bird we saw previously talking to Helen,  paces back and forth agitatedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've sent for the cashier, gentlemen.  He has a list of the loans that Dickson  made last month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he stops in his pacing a moment and  addresses the directors further:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as I told you at breakfast, it is  time we did something about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In thorough accord with Clark's violent  attitude is Schultz, a German, whose  instinctive conservatism rebels against  Dickson's liberal banking methods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Clark's right. Dickson will ruin  this bank if we don't stop him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks to me as if we're in hot water  already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very dignified but meek little old  man, Jonathan Ives, tries horning in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As another of the directors, O'Brien,  a large, bull-faced, thunderous-voiced  contractor, rises to Dickson's defense.  (O'Brien is always filing his nails,  even while he talks.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Personally, I think you're getting panic-stricken  about nothing. Dickson's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, is he? We carry more unsecured paper  than any other institution in the city.  We're fools to tolerate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I say. And the only way  to end it is to get Dickson out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson doesn't have to go. But he must  agree to this merger with New York TrustВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What good will that do? Why, it will  take control away from him. We'll put  somebody else in charge, call in all  doubtful loans, and be on safe ground  again. That's what good it will do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Including Ives in scene with Clark and  O'Brien. Ives is seated, O'Brien and  Clark standing by table. Ives tries  to speak again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has just occurred to meВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're wasting your time, I tell you.  Dickson won't stand for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll stand for it, if I have anything  to say about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then they hear door open, and they  all look towards door leading thru to  main floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he shuts the door behind him. He  is immaculately groomed, obviously cuts  quite a dash with the women. He looks  off toward the men as Clark's voice  comes in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS WITH CLUETT as he comes  forward and puts a paper on the table  before Clark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cluett exits toward door again. Clark  picks up the list and looks at it. Then  he addresses the other men:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this. Just look at this. It's  outrageous. Henry Moore - thirty-six  thousand. Manny Goldberg - eighty-five  hundred. Tony Consero - fifty-six thousand  dollars. Joseph McDonald - eighteen  thousand. Alvin Jones - sixty-six thousand  dollars to a hotel that's on its last  legs. I tell you, people get loans in  this bank that couldn't borrow five  cents anywhere else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the other men group around the loan  list, which Clark has put back down  on the table. They all scrutinize it  carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And on what? "Hunches," he calls it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some day he'll get a "hunch" about a  man and give the bank away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's almost done that already. Our chief  teller, Matt Brown, is an example of  that. He breaks into Dickson's house,  holds him up, and the next day gets  a job in the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, as far as I'm concernedВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boy who should be in jail, handling  a bank's cash!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29. INT. MAIN FLOOR OF BANK - MED. CLOSE  SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting toward Matt, inside the teller's  cage, busily counting the money he is  getting ready for Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A friend of mine - yeah, really - his  mother was terribly sick and she was  dying, would you believe it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'm lying. Don't forget you  called me a liar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches forward and takes her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh honey, why don't we get married?  Then you can handle it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then Oscar enters the scene, en  route somewhere. He stops beside Matt,  notices he and Helen are holding hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Helen and Matt separate guiltily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, Matt! Matt! Did you hear the news?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me. All the big shots are in  a huddle, and it looks like Dickson's  out on his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen and Matt react to this piece of  news. They look at one another. Apparently,  it will have a definite effect on their  lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're kidding me, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not kidding. Everybody's talking  about it. Ask her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's on the level, there goes my  assistant cashier's job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I just thought I'd drop by and  cheer you up a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he turns to go out of scene, he looks  at Matt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be seeing you, Matt - in the breadline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are all gathered around the  table now. Apparently, they have been  discussing ways and means of ousting  Dickson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we cut to this scene, Ives is pouring  himself a glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ham I had this morning was very  saltyВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, let's get organized before  Dickson gets here. Schultz, can I count  on you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Schultz, who is seated next to Clark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Ames, who is seated next to Schultz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the way I feel about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the way I look at it, it seems  thatВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At other end of table, where O'Brien  is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you've got an awful fight on your  hands. That's all I've got to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I think it's time that we  do fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42. INT. MAIN FLOOR OF BANK - FULL SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The outer offices of the bank are in  this shot. A spacious stretch of desks  occupied by clerks and junior officers,  all busily at work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wizened old doorman is greeting clerks  as they arrive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning. You're on time this morning.  It's about time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Dickson, looming in the doorway,  for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Dickson stops to speak to the doorman.  Dickson is a man of about fifty, whose  looks belie his years. There is a robustness  and virility about him that is compelling.  His very walk radiates power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He now puts his hand on the old man's  shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, how's your wife this morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much better this morning, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gardiner hurriedly produces a handkerchief,  and starts to blow his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he takes the handkerchief, and polishes  the brass on Gardiner's uniform)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you feel this morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That makes it unanimous. I feel all  right too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smile on his face disappears as  he sees something which annoys him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young man looks up quickly. He is  smoking a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the rules about smoking . .  .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carter quickly crushes out the cigarette.  Even as he does so, Dickson reaches  into his pocket and flips Carter a fresh  one, which Carter pockets for later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt looks up. Dickson tosses him a  wink, and Matt winks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson walks on towards his office.  CAMERA TRUCKS AHEAD OF HIM. On the way  he is greeted by his employees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Dickson. Etc., etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is joined by Bill Saunders, a friend  of his. Bill walks along with Dickson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You here again? What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does not stop. Continues his walk  toward his office. Bill along-side of  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you suppose anybody wants? Money,  money, money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I told you I wasn't interested  in that deal, didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson notices a man, a janitor without  a uniform, passing by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Where's your uniform?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My goodness, you ought to have a uniform.  How much does one cost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see Sampson. Tell him I sent you.  You've got to have a uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man exits scene. Bill picks up the  conversation where he left off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, I never had trouble getting credit  from you before. When I was flat broke  you gave me all the money I wanted.  Now I come to you with a swell deal,  and the greatestВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you why. I don't like the  crowd you're mixed up with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Personally, you can have all the credit  you want. But for that deal - not a  cent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have now reached the anteroom of  Dickson's private chamber, where Helen  sits at her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45. INT. DICKSON'S OUTER OFFICE - MED.  CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Dickson comes up to Helen at her  desk. A lady sits nearby. Dickson notices  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen, you're becoming more beautiful  every day. What are we going to do about  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess we'll just have to sacrifice the  bank. When are you and Matt going to  get married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, the directors are waiting for you  in the board room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't got any new stories for them  this morning, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Pembroke has been standing by,  waiting to get a word in edgewise. CAMERA  PANS SLIGHTLY with him to take in the  lady:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Mrs. Pembroke. I spoke to Mr. Schaffer  at the Guaranty. He's going to take  care of that mortgage for you . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this speech the phone bell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Helen picks up the phone and quietly  answers it. Bill Saunders is standing  nearby, still waiting to talk to Dickson  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson comes over to the desk and as  he picks up the receiver, he looks toward  Mrs. Pembroke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better hurry over there. He's  waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you? . . . Sure, well, come  on down right away. Huh? . . . Yes,  of course I remember. It's tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See what a social hound I'm becoming!  . . . All right, goodbye, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up. Mrs. Pembroke is waiting  for him to finish. She has apparently  been disappointed in the news he has  for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Mr. Dickson, I thought you were  going to take care of the mortgage.  I only want ten thousand. The property  is worth sixty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Schaffer will take good care of  you. He'll give you fifteen - maybe  twenty . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He continues talking to the lady, trying  to get rid of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better hurry now. Goodbye. Good luck  to you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Pembroke, bewildered, starts to  leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS WITH HIM as Mrs. Pembroke  leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, if Mrs. Dickson comes in, will you  tell her to see Cluett if she needs  any money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill Saunders is still waiting. He corners  Dickson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the idea of turning her down?  It sounds like a perfectly safe investment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a widow. I don't like taking mortgages  from widows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she can't pay, I'll have to foreclose,  won't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to address a man below - the  janitor without a uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abruptly, he heads for the board room.  Bill is still baffled by Dickson's queer  reasoning. Suddenly, it dawns on him.  He shakes his head admiringly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blithely; as he counts the board members  present)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One - two - three - four - five. Seven  more and you'd have a jury!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs a walking cane and wields it  like a golf putter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's a nice morning, gentlemen.  How about two foursomes of golf?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I say, that would be . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ives's voice trails off as he realizes  Clark is scowling at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, you know, I found out something  yesterday about hitting a golf ball.  You've got to hit with the left hand,  and from the inside out, it's the only  way you can hit anythingВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think, Mr. Dickson, we would like  to have a little of your very valuable  time here at the bank this morning,  if you don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you would, eh? All right. If it's  more important than golf, go ahead.  What's on your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 51. INT. LOBBY OF BANK - LONG SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting from one end of the lobby toward  the front door. Depositors are scattered  all over the place. Some at the windows.  Some at the writing tables. Others sitting  inside the railing, talking to junior  executives. The scene is peaceful, though  very active.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA STARTS TRUCKING FORWARD, passing  en route, the different types of individuals  who frequent the bank. People from all  walks of life. CAMERA TRAVELS SLOWLY,  picking up following little scenes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The check is no good. The man has no  account here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So am I. And don't call me madam!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA NEXT PICKS UP an elderly lady  talking to a bank guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am, you can deposit your money  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's his life insurance money, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right. You come with me,  and I'll show you where to deposit your  money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA GOES PAST and now singles out  three men who are coming forward. One  glance and we know they are here for  no kosher reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are typical gangster types. One  of them, the leader, is dressed in everything  but the kitchen sink. Light fedora,  stiff shirt and collar with stripes  running perpendicularly. Flashy gray  suit - spats - and walking stick. The  other two are just tough hombres, but  dressed to kill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they walk toward camera, they glance  around the bank with a professional  casualness, but obviously very much  impressed. Their eyes rove around the  place and finally land on some object  where they stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he quickly counts out several thousand  dollars in bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their eyes glisten. Their mouths water,  as they watch Charlie off scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the railing. Cluett emerges from  his office and starts forward, business-like,  when he suddenly stops in his tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares off at the racketeers. A look  of fright comes into his eyes. His impulse  is to turn back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three gangsters. A quick flash.  Their eyes light on Cluett off scene,  and they glare menacingly at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He changes his mind about avoiding them.  His face breaks into a feeble smile  of affability as he walks toward them.  CAMERA PANS WITH HIM as he approaches  the three men, his hand outstretched  in forced amiability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning! Who do you want to see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gangsters shake hands with him,  their expressions remaining unchanged,  which adds immeasurably to Cluett's  discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. We wanna talk to you about a big  deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a sinister significance in  the manner in which he emphasizes "a  big deal." Cluett is perceptibly ill-at-ease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Well, come right this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the swinging gate in front  of him, permitting the three racketeers  to enter. They start for Cluett's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 58. INT. ANTE ROOM DICKSON'S OFFICE  - MED. CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen sits at her typewriter near a  railing, overlooking the bank below.  Another girl stands by her, both are  staring off scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 59. INT. BANK LOBBY - MED. LONG SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cluett and the three gangsters going  into Cluett's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60. INT. ANTE ROOM OF DICKSON'S OFFICE  - MED. CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Dude Finlay, all right - I've  seen his picture in the papers hundreds  of times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder what he's doing with Mr. Cluett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, I'm scared. He's one of the toughest  gangsters in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 61. INT. CONFERENCE ROOM - MED. LONG  SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting down the length of the table.  The men are all sitting around the large  table. Dickson is on his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, you're only wasting your  time. There'll be no merger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I turn this bank over to  anybody else? I've worked twenty-five  years night and day to build it up,  and now you're asking me to dump it  into somebody's lapВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schultz, who is seated near Dickson,  looks up at him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can make a handsome profit on your  stock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in profits. I'm interested  in the bank. In the depositors. They're  my friends. They're looking to me for  protection, and I'm not walking out  on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark and O'Brien, also seated around  close to Dickson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you protecting your depositors?  By making a lot of idiotic loans!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ives, seated next to Schultz, becomes  alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. Let him go ahead. Let  him speak his piece. I like it. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. I'll speak my piece. Dickson,  you've got to change your policy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with my policy? How  many losses has this bank taken in the  last twenty-five years?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you. Not a single one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with that kind of banking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ames, seated beyond Ives, now speaks  up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conditions have changed. These are precarious  times. Banks today have got to be careful.  And you've been more liberal than ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson's voice comes in over scene:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, and I'm going to continue to be  liberal . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trouble with this country today  is there's too much hoarded cash. Idle  money is no good to industry. Where  is all the money today? In the banks,  vaults, socks, old tin cans, buried  in the ground! I tell you, we've got  to get the money in circulation before  you'll get this country back to prosperity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are we going to give it to? Men  like Jones? Last week you made him an  extra loan of fifty thousand dollars.  Do you call that intelligent banking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't pay his bills. How do you expect  him to pay us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a fair question, Schultz. Now  let's see how bad a risk Jones is. What's  his history? He's been a successful  business man for thirty-five years.  Two years ago business started falling  off. Today Jones needs money, and if  he doesn't get it, he goes into bankruptcy  and throws nine hundred men out of work.  Answer - unemployment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he listens intently, Dickson's voice  coming in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It also means his creditors aren't paid.  They're in trouble. They go to banks  and are turned down . . . more bankruptcies  . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a vicious circle, my friends, and  the only place to cure it is right here  at the source. Help Jones and you help  the whole circle. Now, when Jones comes  to me, I ask myself two questions. First  - is he honest? Yes. Second - is he  as good a business man as he was before?  And the answer is - he's better .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing his reaction, as part of Dickson's  speech comes over scene:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is not only older and wiser, but  his present trouble has taught him precaution.  In my estimation, gentlemen, Jones is  no risk. Neither are the thousands of  other Joneses throughout the country  . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group, as Dickson concludes his  speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's they who built this nation up to  the richest in the world, and it's up  to the banks to give them a break. Disraeli  said security is the prosperity of the  nationВ—[4]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Disraeli didn't say anything of  the kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he should have said it. It's as  true now as it was then. And let us  get the right kind of security. Not  stocks and bonds that zig-zag up and  down, not collateral on paper, but character!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. That's Alexander Hamilton's  idea[5] - the finest banking mind this  country has ever known. Those are his  exact words, gentlemen. Character! It's  the only thing you can bank on, and  it's the only thing that will pull this  country out of the doldrums.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 75. INT. CLUETT'S PRIVATE OFFICE - MED.  CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cluett sits at his desk, his face drawn,  panic-stricken. He is like an animal  at bay. The leader of the trio, Dude  Finlay, sits in a chair directly in  front of Cluett. The other two men stand  on either side of the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what we do to welchers, Cluett,  don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know, Dude. Oh, I must have  been crazy! I lost my head completely!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your funeral. We've got fifty  thousand dollars comin' to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what did you want to gamble for?  If you'd have beat us out of fifty G's,  you'd have been paid, wouldn't you?  Well, we want our dough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That don't do us any good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But after all, you can't take blood  from a stone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can take blood from anything В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting toward Cluett. Dude on opposite  side of desk, the other two men still  standing by the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A look of alarm spreads over Cluett's  face. There is nothing hidden in this  threat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps if you'll wait a little while,  I might be ableВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now - what's the use of getting excited,  Cluett? It oughta be easy for you to  lay your mitts on that kind of dough  . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting past Dude, as Dude continues,  slowly, deliberately:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's plenty of it in this bank -  laying around loose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good heavens, man! You're not suggesting  that IВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to do nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cluett looks up toward the men - then  at Dude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you gotta do is fix a few things  for us , and we'll do the rest, see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a pause while Cluett stares  at them, horrified, his confused mind  trying to assimilate the ghastliness  of their proposal. Suddenly he starts  to rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Cluett gets to his feet and faces  Dude across the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, I couldn't - I couldn't do anything  like that. IВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smack! The rest of his speech dies in  his throat. The man to his right has  slapped him across the face with his  open palm. Taken unaware, Cluett's hand  goes to his cheek. He stares at them,  bewildered and frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cluett, feeling himself trapped and  helpless, slowly sinks into his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 80. INT. ANTEROOM DICKSON'S OFFICE -  MED. SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen sits at her typewriter. A very  dignified, beautiful woman of thirty  approaches her. She is Phyllis Dickson,  Dickson's wife. She radiates refinement  and culture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Helen's desk, as Helen looks up at  Mrs. Dickson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that busy husband of mine busy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Board meeting. Oh, that means hours,  I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen, did you ever try competing with  a bank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, take my word for it, and don't  try it. It's useless! If it were some  other woman, I could handle her, but  after all, you can't scratch a bank's  eyes out now, can you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well. I guess the only other thing  for me to do is to go out and buy myself  a few sticks of dynamite. When he comes  out, you tell him I'll be back. He hasn't  gotten rid of me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen laughs as Mrs. Dickson leaves  in the direction of Cluett's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 84. INT. CYRIL CLUETT'S OFFICE - MED.  CLOSE SHOT AT DOOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three racketeers are preparing to  leave. Dude has his hand on the doorknob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dude - there's not any chance of my  becoming involved in this, is there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You? No, you'll be all right, so long  as you establish an alibi for tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be sure you're with somebody responsible  in case any questions are asked. Understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Dude, listen - couldn't we make  this some other time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, buddy, you're getting by pretty  easy. Quit squawking!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cluett looks at Dude, then at the others,  and realizes he is helpless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the door and the men file out,  silently. Cluett shuts the door and  CAMERA PANS WITH HIM as he crosses back  to his desk, shaking perceptibly. He  reaches into a desk drawer and extracts  a bottle of liquor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he takes a drink, Mrs. Dickson enters  unannounced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mrs. Dickson stands watching Cluett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cluett turns quickly. Upon seeing her,  he makes an attempt to conceal the terror  he feels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She advances toward him as he rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This won't do. Not during business hours  . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavens, no! Do you mind putting up  with me until the financial genius gets  thru genius-ing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, of course not. Not at all. Oh,  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she takes out a cigarette, he offers  her a light. Mrs. Dickson notices that  he is rather nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the matter with you? You're  trembling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I? Why, I - I don't know any reason  why I should be, unless of course it's  you . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being alone with you has always done  this to me. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a celebrated bounder, that is an  awful admission. Besides, I never knew  that any female could do this to you  .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you can. You always could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liar! You're just suffering from lack  of sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes this as premature defeat, and  heads back toward his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, here, here, now! Don't you go  back to work on me, too. I'm getting  tired of this. Besides, it's beginning  to affect your looksВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I thought you were the slightest  bit interested, I would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad, not bad at all. Do you know  something? I've always been curious  about your line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever it is that makes you such a  riot with women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Cyril, try a little bit of it  out on me. I haven't had any first-class  blarney thrown at me since the day I  was married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you see, it isn't blarney where  you're concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let me see, what comes next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, I know - what are you doing  tonight, Phyllis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is suddenly reminded of his pact  with Dude Finlay. Terror returns to  his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly gets an idea. He was told  to be with someone around midnight.  Someone who would be an alibi for him.  He stares off at Phyllis Dickson. Why  not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, it does. What are you doing  tonight, Phyllis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark is in a state of agitation. The  other directors seem worn by the ordeal.  Dickson remains adamant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the creditors I know personally.  I've seen them grow up in the community.  I knew their fathers and mothers before  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, Dickson. That's all very well.  But you're taking too many chances.  In these times a bank should keep liquid  in case of trouble. In case of emergency!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the men in the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you mean by that. You want  me to hang on to our cash. Well, I don't  believe in it. The law demands that  I carry a certain legal reserve, and  I'm doing it. The rest of our money  is out working . . . working to help  industry . . . to help build up business  . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he almost shouts at Dickson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the meantime, you're jeopardizing  the safety of the bank. Well, we won't  stand for it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the group, as Dickson turns to Clark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to stand for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meek little Ives once again tries to  say something:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're forcing us to take action against  you, Dickson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead - take all the action you want!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks about at the others as he continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm running this bank my way. Get that  clear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, you notice Mr. Dickson refuses  to consider our wishes. He refuses an  offer to merge with the New York Trust  - the only thing that will put this  bank on safe ground. He insists upon  running a bank on so flimsy a thing  as . . . as faith!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! You said it, Clark. That's the  only thing that means anything to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Dickson's voice continues. Clark  reacts appropriately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before I take a man into this bank,  and before I extend credit to anyone,  I satisfy myself on one thing - do I  believe in him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other men - CAMERA PANNING from  one to the other as Dickson's voice  comes over the shot - finally CAMERA  STOPS on Dickson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So far, my judgement has been right  one hundred per cent. One hundred per  cent! When I start going wrong, you  won't have to take any action. I'll  turn the bank over to you. Then you  can

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: merge all you want to. I won't be the  fellow to run it then. Good day, gentlemen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA TRUCKS AHEAD OF HIM as Dickson  passes briskly through his outer office,  stopping only to speak to Helen at her  desk:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen, tell Matt I want to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 96. INT. CLUETT'S PRIVATE OFFICE - CLOSE  SHOT - CLUETT AND PHYLLIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—and after dinner, we could goВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Oh, no! I think I've done enough  experimenting for one day. Congratulations,  Cyril. You've convinced me that you're  a philanderer of the very first order.  I shall recommend you highly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, please don't laugh at me, Phyllis.  I must see you tonight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight, Oh, never! Tonight I have reserved  for a very special occasion. Believe  it or not, it's our wedding anniversary.  Tom doesn't probably even remember it.  But then, they never do, do they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm giving a party for him - a real,  old-fashioned surprise party. Caps,  bells, whistles, and everything. I'm  really terribly excited about it. I've  been planning it for months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, aren't you going to invite me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You? No can do. It's all set. Just a  few of Tom's closest friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Phyllis, if you don't invite me,  I'm coming anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be silly, Cyril. These are respectable  people. They'd probably bore you to  death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they won't. Not when you are there.  Oh, please, be a sport. Please ask me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be near you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you know I've been crazy about  you for years?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute, wait a minute . .  .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've loved you ever since I can remember,  long before you married Tom Dickson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No, I'm not. I deliberately avoided  you. I was afraid of making a fool of  myself. But I won't stand it any longerВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before she realizes what has happened,  he has swept her into his arms and crushes  her to him. CAMERA PANS AWAY from them  to the door to the outer office. The  door opens and Matt steps in. He stops,  suddenly, transfixed by what he sees  off scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis Dickson in Cluett's arms (from  Matt's angle). They suddenly become  conscious of someone in the room and  Phyllis struggles free, looking off  scene toward Matt:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Cluett and Mrs. Dickson's angle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares unbelievingly for a moment,  and then collecting himself, turns and  leaves the room, closing the door after  him. CAMERA PANS BACK to Cluett and  Mrs. Dickson. For a moment she is terribly  upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please forgive me, Phyllis. I lost my  head for a minute. But I couldn't help  it, Phyllis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she starts for the door, CAMERA PANS  WITH HER. Cluett walks with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please stop apologizing so much. You're  making it far too important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 100. INT. ANTE ROOM OF CLUETT'S OFFICE  - MED. SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt stands there, in a daze. Cluett's  secretary is not there. He starts slowly  forward, hardly knowing where he is  going - CAMERA TRUCKING AHEAD OF HIM  - there is a far-away look in his eyes.  His hand clutches the list of payrolls  but as far as he is concerned, it is  entirely forgotten. Several people talk  to him, but Matt walks on heedlessly.  He can't get over the shock of what  he just saw. He always had been under  the impression that Dickson's home life  was a happy one. He never dreamed that  Phyllis Dickson represented anything  but the height of circumspection. And  now - Cyril Cluett, of all people!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen comes running into scene, all  excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt, where have you been? Mr. Dickson  wants to see you right away. Hurry up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns around mechanically and continues  to walk in the direction of Dickson's  office - CAMERA TRUCKING AFTER HIM.  Helen falls into step with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, I just heard the merger isn't going  thru. Isn't that grand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach Dickson's outer office. Matt  crosses it and exits into the private  office. Helen looks after him - her  face falls in disappointment. Matt is  acting very strangely. She thought he'd  be elated. She stares unhappily at his  forlorn figure as it disappears thru  the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 101. INT. DICKSON'S PRIVATE OFFICE -  MED. SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson sits at his desk when Matt enters.  When he sees Matt, his face breaks into  a broad, pleasant smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Matt, get ready for the big moment.  Starting tomorrow you become assistant  cashier. How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt crosses to the desk as Dickson  is speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Matt stops in front of Dickson. Matt  cannot share Dickson's enthusiasm. The  scene he just witnessed has taken the  joy out of everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what's more, keep up the good work  and who knows - some day you'll be the  fellow sitting behind that desk . .  .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly notices Matt's lack of enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans forward to look at Matt closely:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? You don't seem very  excited about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, come on. Show a little enthusiasm.  What's the matter? Are you sick or something?  Go on, fake it - even if it isn't real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt makes an attempt to snap out of  it - and answers quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, I'm sorry, Mr. Dickson. It's just  kind of sudden, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I'm excited. I think it's great.  Only, well, you've done so much for  me already . . . I'll never be able  to thank you enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, go on, forget it. You came through,  didn't you? That's all I wanted. A lot  of them didn't think you would. You  don't know how much satisfaction it's  been to me. It's been swell. Well, when  are you and Helen going to get married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you want me to fix that up  for you too, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are interrupted by the sudden appearance  of Phyllis Dickson. Both men look up  as she appears in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she stops in doorway. She glances  fearfully, first at Matt and then at  her husband, trying to sense whether  Matt has said anything. She is quickly  assured by Dickson's affable greeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Dickson comes toward her, arms extended:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, look who's here! Hello, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her. Then throws his arms  around her for an exaggerated "teddybear"  hug. Over Dickson's shoulder, Phyllis  looks gratefully at Matt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He returns her glance. His eyes are  unable to disguise his contempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson and Phyllis. He releases her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this isn't a red-letter day for Tom  Dickson! First I trample on the Board  of Directors, then I promote Matt here  to assistant cashier, and now to complete  the day I have a visit from my sweet  and lovely and gorgeous wife. What a  man, what a man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's amazing that your sweet, lovely,  gorgeous wife can ever get to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He notices Matt, still standing there,  uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you still here? Go on - go to work!  What do you think I pay you for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 110. INT. ANTE ROOM OF DICKSON'S PRIVATE  OFFICE - MEDIUM SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Matt comes out and moves quickly  forward as if anxious to get away from  the embarrassing situation he found  himself in. Helen, upon seeing him,  jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened? What did he say? Did  you get the job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is perplexed by his unenthusiastic  attitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Matt? Gee, I thought  you'd be thrilled to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, a few minutes ago I was in  Cluett's office and Mrs. Dickson was  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he was making love to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen, although she had a vague suspicion,  is shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Matt, you must be mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you, I saw them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, right in his office, the rat. I'd  like to take a crack at that guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she goes to answer the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Now don't go away . .  .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 112. INT. DICKSON'S PRIVATE OFFICE -  MED. CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson is seated with Mrs. Dickson  on the arm of the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (talking on the phone, as Mrs Dickson  waits patiently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes George . . . yes, sure . . . Oh,  that's for tonight, eh? . . . Yes, certainly,  I'll be there . . . Yes, we'll go down  together and have dinner in Philadelphia  . . . Mrs. Dickson gets so upset . .  . That's right. . . . Yeah. . . . Just  as soon as the bank closes. . . . Right.  . . . Goodbye. . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He punches the intercom, speaks to Helen  in the outer office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen, I'm going to Philadelphia, just  as soon as the bank closes. Make all  the arrangements, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Dickson looks visibly upset. Dickson  can't help but notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter dear? What have I  done now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Tom, I thought you were going  out with me tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I did have a date with you tonight,  didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm terribly sorry. I'd forgotten all  about you. I'm so sorry, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Tom, you simply cannot go to Philadelphia  tonight. That's all there is to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I have to go, dear. It's a very  important banker's meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care whether it's important  or not. You said you were going out  with me, and if you hadn't promised  so faithfully, I wouldn't have gone  and planned the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, it isn't so terribly important.  We can go to the theatre any time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what it was you planned, wasn't  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can take some of the girls. You  can take Mildred - or GwynnВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls! I don't suppose it ever occurred  to you that I might go out and find  myself an attractive young man . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting toward Dickson, as he laughs  boisterously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ho, ho, ho, yourself! I wouldn't laugh  if I were you. You may not suspect it,  but I'm still attractive - to some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, don't go around being attractive  to anyone but me . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you forget that I'm still the  head man around here too. Now we'll  get the tickets changed for tomorrow  night. You and I are going out together.  How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A buzzer sounds, and a visitor is announced  on the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. That's that lawyer. All right,  let him have nine thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir, I'll step you around this town  like you've never stepped before. We  will have dinner at the St. Regis -  then we'll go to a nice, snappy show  - then a nightclub - we'll listen to  soft music, and who knows? Ha! - I might  break down and dance with you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. I'll postpone the whole thing  until tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her in his arms and kisses  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor kid, you know, I have been neglecting  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't care, darling. I love you,  anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A buzzer sounds again, and Dickson answers  the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock on the door. Dickson  moves away from his wife. He looks toward  the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sampson, an executive in the bank, enters.  Sampson goes to Dickson with some papers  in his hand. He lays the papers on the  desk before Dickson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the data on the Clyde deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. I'll take this along with me.  Tell Clyde I'll see him tomorrow. I'm  sick and tired of the delay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just exactly what he has been  doing. This deal should have been closed  weeks ago. Tell him to keep tomorrow  open . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says he can't get away in the daytime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about his nights? He's too busy  running around. Tell him to keep tomorrow  night open, come in and sign this thing,  or I'll call this whole deal off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands by a window, listening. There  is despair in her look as she hears  him making arrangements for tomorrow  night. Dickson's voice comes over this  shot:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sick and tired of these people dilly-dallying.  People who can't make up their minds  . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Dickson's eyes close hopelessly,  and she feels defeated. Again shut out  from his scheme of things, she realizes  he is incurable. On this picture of  resignation:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: CLOCK OVER THE VAULT, reading  5:07

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS DOWN to open vault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, several of the tellers are putting  their cash away. One of them is just  entering with his truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie's upstairs as sore as a pup.  He's out fourteen cents, and he can't  find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 122. OUTSIDE OF VAULT - MED. CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cyril Cluett is standing at the bottom  of a spiral staircase from which he  has just descended. He stops a second  and watches Matt, off scene. Cluett  has gloves on, his hat in his hand,  preparatory to going home. Matt does  not see Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 123. OUTSIDE OF THE VAULT - CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt and Helen standing near the vault  door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say Matt, you haven't done anything  about what you saw today, have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Cluett? No, not yet. But I'd like  to take a crack at that stiff-necked,  horse dollar.[6]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you imagine that guy? He was kissing  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you've got me worried, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise me you won't butt in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, honey - but just the same I'd  like to take a crack at thatВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts her hand over her mouth:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves. Matt remains standing, a  far-away look in his eyes. It is obvious  he is thinking about the thing seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys who were inside the vault now  file out, having properly locked away  their cash. At the same time, Charlie  wheels in his truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you think I've been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took the baby for a stroll in the  park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men hurry out of sight, laughing.  Charlie disappears into the vault. Matt  enters the vault, his mind still preoccupied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Matt goes directly to the burglar  alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Matt's hand comes into scene and  throws the switch down toward sign reading  ON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt starts to the vault door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fourteen cents out, and it took  me half an hour to find the mistake.  And me with a date, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember once when your account checked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt goes to the time clock to check  it up. He tinkers with it a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 126. OUTSIDE OF VAULT - MED. CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt has just finished adjusting the  time clock as Charlie comes out of the  vault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And listen, wise guy - I'm setting friend  time clock for exactly nine o'clock,  so no squawks out of you guys in the  morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, don't annoy me. I got troubles  of my own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt smiles. He starts to shut the vault.  He has it swinging half-way around when  Cluett enters. When Matt sees Cluett,  the smile dies on his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are the payrolls ready for tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see your cash book, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt looks at him a moment antagonistically.  He has half a mind to talk to him right  now, but he recalls Helen's admonitions  and thinks better of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits into vault. The moment he is  gone, Cluett crosses quickly to the  time clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Cluett's gloved hand comes in and  turns the indicator back to 12 o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt has opened a compartment and has  brought out several sheets of paper.  He goes thru them to find the one he  wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cluett's hand is seen throwing the switch  up to indicator reading OFF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Matt comes up to Cluett with a cash  report. Cluett glances over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right. But it seems to me  you're carrying too much cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits. Matt glares belligerently  at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS with him as he returns the  paper to compartment. He locks the compartment  door, switches off the light in vault  and CAMERA PANS WITH HIM as he starts  out of the vault. As he swings the large  vault door closed,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 128. EXT. SIDEWALK IN FRONT OF APT.  HOUSE - NIGHT - MED. SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a cab drives up to curb in the middle  of a downpour, and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 129. INT. TAXICAB - CLOSE SHOT - CLUETT  AND MRS. DICKSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are in evening clothes, apparently  they had some drinks, as phyllis is  in a gay, frivolous mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew I couldn't trust you. You told  me you were taking me home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on up for just a few minutes. We'll  have just one drink, then we'll go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I know the answer to that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'd better take me home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Afraid papa will  spank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No, I'm afraid papa isn't that much  interested. He's too busy rushing off  to Philadelphia to make stuffy, old  speeches at stuffy, old bankers' meetings.  Too busy closing big, important dealsВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I will have a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 131. INT. CORRIDOR OUTSIDE CLUETT'S  APT. - MED. CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cluett and Mrs. Dickson emerge from  the elevator and cross to his apartment,  CAMERA FOLLOWING THEM. Cluett fumbles  in his pocket for the key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, there ought to be a Congressional  Medal for men like you. America's comfort  to misunderstood wives. I never thought  I would find myself in that class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're not so badly off. There's  something much worse than being a misunderstood  wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cluett smiles. He has the door open  by now and stands aside to permit her  to enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 132. INT. CLUETT'S APARTMENT - MED.  CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At door. Phyllis Dickson has just stepped  in, and Cluett follows. He closes the  door and locks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now fair woman, I have you in my  power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid of you. You haven't got  a moustache!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll grow a moustache by the time you  get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA TRUCKS WITH THEM as he chases  her into the next room. She alights  on a piano bench, and runs her fingers  up and down the scales. Suddenly Cluett  stops. He stares off, a look of amazement  in his face. Mrs. Dickson turns and  follows his gaze and she, too, is startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS QUICKLY over to the other  side of the room. Matt sits on the edge  of a chair waiting for them. He rises,  looks off toward Cluett and Mrs. Dickson.  As he starts forward, CAMERA PANS BACK  to Cluett and Phyllis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The butler said I could stay. I told  him it was important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cluett steps over to a bell cord and  pulls it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not here. He left at nine o'clock.  He said you gave him the night off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I thought I'd like to have a little  talk with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's funny - now that I'm here, I don't  know just how to go about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, I kind of expected to find  you here alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind stepping outside? We could  talkВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cluett crosses to the door, where he  stands, ready to open it. Mrs. Dickson  stands by helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything you have to say to me, you  can say in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, Mr. Cluett, if it's all the same  to you, I'd rather not wait. It's about  you and Mrs. Dickson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cluett releases his hold on the doorknob.  Mrs. Dickson looks at Matt uneasily  - she is quickly sobering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why Matt, what are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I've got a lot of nerve butting  in like this, but I just couldn't help  it. I thought I could stop two people  from doing something they'd be sorry  for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in what you think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've no right to do this to her, Mr.  Cluett. Why don't you think it over?  It's only gonna get you into a lot of  trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you, I'm not interested in your  opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? Then maybe you'll understand, Mrs.  Dickson. Oh, gee, he's crazy about you.  Nobody knows it better than you. If  he ever finds out, it'll kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Matt, you're mistaken about the  whole thing. There isn't anything wrong.  Mr. Cluett and I simply came hereВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis, you don't have to explain anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd do well to mind your own business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my business. Mr. Dickson's been  like a father to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What has he ever done to you to deserve  a deal like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That will be just about enough! Now  get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I have said enough

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just wasting my breath talking to  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking in Mrs. Dickson, who stands slightly  apart from the two men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right for the first time. Now  get out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt ignores Cluett and looks toward  phyllis Dickson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm appealing to you, Mrs. Dickson.  Think what you're doing to him. You're  passing up the whitest man on earthВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before he finishes the sentence, Cluett  punches him. Matt, caught unawares,  is thrown off balance and sent reeling.  He drops between two chairs. Now, livid  with rage, he pulls himself up, murder  in his eyes. Cluett crosses quickly  to a desk near the door, opens a drawer  and extracts a revolver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt, who was started toward Cluett,  stops in his tracks upon seeing the  gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS WITH MATT to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt turns as she enters the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Dickson steps closer to Matt's  side. Cluett comes up to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You needn't go on account of this idiot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better carry that around with you  all the time - you're going to need  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt follows Mrs. Dickson out, leaving  Cluett glaring after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A night watchman, alerted by suspicious  noise, creeping up to the vault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night watchman, shot by figures  in the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small number of men rush out of the  vault, clutching money bags and toting  guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night watchman, getting off a shot,  before he crumples to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 140. INT. VAULT ROOM OF BANK - CLOSEUP  ON DOOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vault door, partly opened. Over  the shot we hear excited murmurs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA STARTS TRUCKING BACK SLOWLY,  until it takes in the full room. A fingerprint  expert is working on the time clock  for finger-print impressions. The medical  examiner bends over the body of the  watchman, whose face is covered with  a cloth. A detective in charge of the  proceedings stands around, looking very  officious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'd say about eight or nine hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you'd better call the coroner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA CONTINUES TRUCKING BACK, until  it passes a group of tellers and clerks  in a huddle. They listen breathlessly  as Oscar, the youngest of the tellers,  relates his story. For the moment he  is the center of attraction, and he  revels in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was the first one to see it. I was  coming down the stairs, and there was  the dead watchman at my feet. You coulda  knocked me over with a pin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you see that clock? Right there.  That's where the bullet hit. When I  saw that, you coulda knocked me over  with a pin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on over fellas. I'll show you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerks head toward the dead body,  but are intercepted by the officious  detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back there . I don't want anything  touched until the Inspector gets here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was the first one to see it. I was  coming down the stairs, and there was  the watchman lying dead at my feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding. When I saw it, you coulda  knocked me over with a pin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He'll have a tough time thinking  up a wise-crack for this one . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The detectives got Matt up there in  Sampson's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
