dialogues.text: Don't look at me. I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, he did look kinda funny yesterday,  didn't you notice it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he did. I noticed it too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You coulda knocked me over with a pin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 141. INT. SAMPSON'S OFFICE - CLOSEUP  - MATT'S FRIGHTENED FACE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits in a chair. The side of his  face is swollen from Cyril Cluett's  punch of the night before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, come on. You might as well  tell me the truth. What did you do with  the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't do it. I told you all I know,  Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA TRUCKS BACK revealing the other  occupants of the room. The Inspector  leans over Matt, firing questions at  him. Two detectives are also there,  one at the door, the other near Matt.  Helen stands in a corner, pale and fearful,  looking on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You turned off the burglar alarm, you  set the time clock, came back at twelve  and emptied the boxes, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't anywhere near this placeВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down! When the watchman surprised  you, you shot him - what'd you do with  the gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't do it! I haven't got a gun!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You used to carry a gun, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me, but I'd like to use my office  for awhile!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 143. INT. LOBBY OF BANK AT ENTRANCE  - MED. CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorman, Gardiner, stands at the  door, blocking a milling crowd, as Dickson,  who apparently has already heard the  news, enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, everybody. What's the  matter here? Open up the door. Come  on, open this door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we let the people come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, let them in! You're late  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA TRUCKS WITH DICKSON as he proceeds  toward interior of bank. Helen rushes  into the scene and up to him. CAMERA  STOPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Dickson - they're going to arrest  Matt. They think he did it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now don't you worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses in that direction, followed  by Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 143. INT. ANTE ROOM OF CLUETT'S OFFICE  - MED. SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cluett comes out of his office, looks  around cautiously and satisfied he is  unobserved, walks toward front door  of bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS over to a corner of the  ante room. Detective #3 is watching  Cluett. As Cluett leaves, the detective  follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt is still seated, with the detectives  grilling him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you did it and you did it aloneВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? What's going on here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous! You can't hold this  boy on a vague suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I must, Mr. Dickson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an inside job. That's a cinch.  Whoever did it had a pretty good picture  of the layout. Now Brown, here, is in  charge of the vaults, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over which comes Inspector's voice as  he continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The burglar alarm was turned off. The  time clock was set for 12 o'clock. What  more do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody else could have done it, couldn't  they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He admits that he set the clock himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did. I set it for nine o'clock this  morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Inspector turns to Matt:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Wait a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector turns back to Dickson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time did this thing happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clock opposite the vault was stopped  by a bullet at 12:09.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. If the boy proves an alibi,  he's all right, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he can do it, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt, now all you've got to do is tell  them where you were last night, between  twelve and twelve-thirty, and everything  will be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already told him I was home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what he says. I got a man from  headquarters checking up on it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got nothing to worry about. Soon  as the report comes in, you'll be released.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And listen, don't talk so loud. Take  it easy. Coast a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 148. INT. THE LOBBY OF THE BANK - FULL  SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing the normal activity of the bank  in contrast to the turmoil going on  inside. Just a few people scattered  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA TRUCKS towards the other end  of the lobby, establishing the calm  and peace of the place along the way.  CAMERA STOPS on a CLOSE SHOT at the  bank telephone operator at the switchboard.  Oscar, the young teller, is relating  his story for the hundredth time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, what do you think? There was that  watchman, that poor watchman, lying  on the floor right in front of me. Oh,  you coulda knocked me over with a pin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead? He was lifeless! You know, I was  the first one to see him. I was coming  down the stairs, and there was the watchman  lying on the floor, right in front of  me. Dead! I tell you, you coulda knockedВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I coulda knocked you over with  a pin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar exits scene. The operator turns  her attention to the switch-board, apparently  Oscar has interrupted a conversation  she has been having.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mame. This is Gert, againВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, listen - I just heard something  that'll make your head swim . . . Listen  to this . . . Yeah, the bank was robbed  last night. Yeah, over a hundred thousand  dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know who did it, but the chief  teller's in an awful jam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me up later. I'm going to call  up Lou now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls the plug, plugs in another  wire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Lou. Did you hear what happened  over at the Union National Bank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Yes, sir. I'm trying to get them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Lou, listen. They was robbed over  two hundred thousand dollars. Can you  beat that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 150. EXT. FRONT OF AN OFFICE BLDG. -  MED. SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two men coming out of the building,  engrossed in conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stole over a quarter of a million. Can  you beat that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other man whistles in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whew! You can't laugh that off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several people in the crowd, overhearing  them, turn and stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 151. EXT. A STREET CORNER - MED. CLOSE  SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of an old lady, pitiful expression,  begging alms. Two gentlemen are beside  her. One of them reaches in his pocket  for a coin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought the Union National was pretty  solid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the mention of the Union National,  the old lady looks up, startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half a million is a lot of money. I  wouldn't be surprised if they had to  close their doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first man drops a coin in the old  lady's palm and they leave. The beggar  woman, oblivious of the coin in her  hand, stares unbelieving, at the departing  men. Suddenly her face screws up in  horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 152. EXT. A BOOTBLACK STAND - MEDIUM  SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A colored bootblack is brushing the  coat of a customer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy, are you sure about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, suh! That messenga boy just tol'  me that Mr. Dickson took it all hisself.  And it was more than a million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cross my heart. And I sure hopes that  man gets a long time in jail, too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 153. INT. A BARBER SHOP - MED. CLOSE  SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking in two chairs. The man on the  right, being shaved, is in conversation  with the barber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I always said the Union National  was a phony bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second customer sits straight up  in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had money in that bank, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mon dieu, mon dieu! Run, run!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second customer dashes out of scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 154. INT. A BAR - MED. CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two men are in conversation. Another  man is alone. One of the two men holding  the conversation is the man of the bootblack  episode.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you, I got it from the best authority.  Dickson got away with several million  dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is just reaching for his glass, and  starts to lift it to his lips when another  man's voice comes into scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, that's the end of the Union National  Bank. That's the trouble nowadays. You  don't know who you can trust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The third man drops the glass and turns  toward the two, panic-stricken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 156. MED. CLOSE SHOT OF THE THREE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, is there something wrong with the  Union National Bank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something wrong? Brother, that ain't  the half of it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you've got any money in there, you  can just kiss it goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rushes out of the scene. The other  two stare after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you've got any friends, you'd better  call them up too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a good idea. I have friends of  my own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to bartender, who has been  eavesdropping with interest)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What bank did you say that was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Union National Bank. They're broke.  Haven't got a dime . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick cuts of excited phone conversations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Jack, go down to the Union National  and take your money out of there. Don't  ask me how I know. I told you it's on  the rocks. If you've got any friends,  you'd better tell them too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better give all the men in your plant  a couple of hours off to get their money  outВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Mrs. Hardy to tell everybody in  the apartment houseВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. I'll get it or bust a few  noses!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy smoke! I'll get right down there  if I have to fly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run down there and get your money at  once!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quick cuts - a rising tide - different  languages)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, dear . . . Hurry! . . . Union  National is sunk! . . . I told you to  put it in the vault . . . I don't know  what's wrong with the bank . . . I wouldn't  trust anybody . . . everybody's taking  their money out . . . Union National's  broken . . . Why take any chances? .  . . Hurry! Call the others! etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 158. INT. LOBBY OF THE BANK - FULL SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing in comparison to previous shot,  the effect of the rumors. The lobby  is buzzing with activity. Lines form  in front of all the windows. Depositors  crowd around the writing tables. There  are not

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: enough pens to go around. Frantic hands  reach over shoulders for withdrawal  blanks. CAMERA MOVES FORWARD. Over the  shot is heard the seething blend of  many voices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA STOPS ON a Teller and a Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. I'm closing my account. I  wouldn't leave a nickel in this bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA STOPS ON a 2nd Man talking to  a Woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's getting so a man's money ain't  safe unless it's in his sock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all a bunch of crooks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA STOPS ON Jewish Man talking to  a 4th Man standing next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, did I know the bank was going to  go caflooey? What am I - a fortune teller  or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA STOPS on a MED. CLOSE SHOT of  Molly (the Zasu Pitts type). She is  reaching over a man's shoulder to capture  a withdrawal blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my goodness! Oh, my goodness! Oh,  my goodness!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, mister, I gotta! I gotta!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they only sign slips here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grabs pen away from him. He turns  to someone next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you loan me that pen of yours?  I'm in an awful hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES ON to a CLOSE SHOT of a  teller frantically beckoning Sampson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need some more money! All of the depositors  are withdrawing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know. I'll get you some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspector is still holding his ground.  Matt sits dejectedly in the same place  as before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I know is the bank's been robbed  and a murder's been committed. The way  I see it, Brown here looks guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? He had no  more to do with it than you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. But I'm taking no chances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, this kid's got a record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So have you. So have I. So's everybody  got a record. What difference does that  make? You can't go around pinning crimes  on people just because theyВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is interrupted by the sound of the  door opening. He looks off toward door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sampson stands there, looking off toward  the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Dickson! Can I see you for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm busy. See me later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this is important, Mr. Dickson.  Looks like there's a run on the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson and the others. Dickson looks  off at Sampson, unbelievingly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? A run on the bank!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS WITH HIM as he rushes over  to the door to Sampson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson goes out the door, followed  by Sampson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 163. OUTER OFFICES OF BANK - MED. CLOSE  SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Sampson and Dickson come into the  scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson looks in the direction in which  Sampson points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 164. INT. LOBBY OF BANK - LONG SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This shot takes in the length of the  bank. Clerks, bookkeepers, stenographers  in the f.g., the lobby in the b.g. It  seems a little more crowded than in  previous shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 164. OUTER OFFICES OF BANK - MED. CLOSE  SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sampson and Dickson. Dickson's face  clouds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've been coming in steady all morning.  I have called for some extra police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Send down to the vaults and  have our reserve cash sent up here right  away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't much on hand, you know. If  it gets any worse, I hope we don't have  to close the doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bank's reputation wouldn't be worth  a nickel after that. This is just a  flurry, that's all. They've heard about  the robbery and got panic-stricken.  Listen, get ahold of our available securities  and have them turned into cash. Wait  a minute. Get my personal stuff and  have that turned into cash too. Tell  the boys anyone caught arguing with  a depositor will be fired on the spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Sampson leaves. Dickson starts out  in the direction of Sampson's office.  He is stopped by his name being called:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson turns. Clark and several directors  appear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll discuss that in the board room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to follow, then is stopped  by another voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Dickson! We got a check on Brown's  alibi. Do you want to hear it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be with you in a minute, Clark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 167. INT. SAMPSON'S OFFICE - MED. CLOSE  SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson is by Matt's side. The Inspector  is also in scene. Dickson puts a hand  on Matt's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now don't worry, son. All you got to  do is answer the questions they ask  you, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS TO THE DOOR as it opens  and a detective enters, beckons to the  Inspector off scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Inspector crosses to the new  arrival, who whispers something in his  ear. The others in the room watch them,  interested. The Inspector whispers instructions  to the detective, who leaves. The Inspector  then crosses slowly to Matt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Inspector comes up to the group  around Matt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you were home last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time did you get in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleven o'clock, eh? Are you sure it  was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector turns away and CAMERA  PANS WITH the Inspector as he crosses  quickly to the door and beckons to the  detective outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelley returns to the room accompanied  by a little old Irish woman. She looks  around the room nervously. Inspector  leads her toward Matt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As everyone stares at her curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know this young man, Mrs. Halligan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I do. He has the best room in me  house. The one with the fancy wallpaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He feels himself cornered. The Inspector's  voice comes over the shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you happen to be awake when he came  in last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. I was having me hot mustard  bath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time was it, Mrs. Halligan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was late, I know. The Dooley sisters  was already in. They work at a show,  you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time did Matt Brown get in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, let me see - a half hour after  the Dooley sisters - and the Dooley  sisters never get home until afterВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care about the Dooley sisters  - what time did he get in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just what I'm trying to tell  you, sir. It was a half hour after the  Dooley sisters . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson, Matt, and the rest of the group.  Some show their amusement. Dickson and  Matt, however, are serious. Mrs. Halligan's  voice comes into scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it wasn't twelve - 'cause the Dooley  sisters . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I guess it was one, 'cause . .  .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know. Cause the Dooley sisters  weren't in yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No - because me clock struck four, and  when it strikes four, it's one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, she doesn't know what she's talking  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Halligan looks at him, offended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen here, young man - nobody ever  called me a liar yet and got away with  itВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspector leads her to the door. On  the way Mrs. Halligan continues to mumble  her protest against Matt's insult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For two nickels I'd knock his block  off. I never told a lie in me life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Dickson steps closer to Matt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspector comes up to them now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it's true - and he knows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Matt. If you don't tell the  truth, I can't help you. Where were  you last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, she was right. I didn't get in till  after one o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I wasn't here, Mr. Dickson. Honest  I wasn't . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Favoring Dickson as he leans closer  to Matt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Wait a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt, do you realize you're up against  something? You're being charged with  murder. It's serious, son. Now come  on, I know you didn't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we've got to make them believe it.  Come on, tell the truth, where were  you last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, if I get them out of the room,  will you tell me ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt looks at him. Dickson is the only  person he cannot tell his secret to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you are. You're protecting somebody.  Now listen, it doesn't make any difference  who it is. It can't be as important  as this. Now come on, tell me. Where  were you last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, don't be a fool. Matt, you  trust me, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No reply from Matt. Dickson is heartsick.  He turns, helplessly, away from Matt  and walks out of Sampson's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 178. INT. THE LOBBY OF THE BANK - CLOSE  SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a day, Mame! Everybody's coming  in and drawing their money out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, Mame - I wonder what started it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 179. THE LOBBY OF THE BANK - LONG SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouting from the offices. The lobby  is now packed to the doors with frantic  depositors. The low grumbling of before  is now replaced by

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: vociferous condemnation of the bank  and Dickson. Individual protestations  are heard above the din of the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson enters scene, and CAMERA TRUCKS  AHEAD OF HIM as he quickly passes several  tellers, giving them instructions to  pay the depositors without delay. Sampson  catches up with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at them, Mr. Dickson. They're going  crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get the case for the securities?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. But soon as our money runs  out, they'll mob the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson looks off toward the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fools! If they only knew it, they're  making things worse for themselves.  Somebody starts a silly rumor, and they  lose their heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll talk to them. Listen, go back and  tell the boys to stall as much as possible.  Tell 'em not to pay any attention to  what I said. Tell 'em to verify every  signature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves the scene as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 180. LOBBY OF THE BANK - LONG SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking in a greater portion of the lobby.  Dickson comes into the scene in the  b.g. and stands on the stairs, looking  down at the crowd. He suddenly holds  up his hand and shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your time, folks. Don't get excited.  Everybody stay in line. You'll all be  taken care of. Don't worry about anything.  Plenty of time for everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has to raise his voice even louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now listen, everybody! Listen to me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gradually their attention is attracted  to him. All eyes are turned in his direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting toward Dickson, past the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson standing on the stairs. The  people looking up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to know that your money is  safe. This bank is in excellent condition.  If you've heard any reports to the contrary,  it's based on malicious rumors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a lotta hooey! We want our money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. You'll get your money - every  penny!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want it now! We don't want no speeches!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me now. It takes time. I've  got seven paying tellers working just  as fast as they can. If you'll all calm  down, I'm making arrangements to keep  the doors open until four o'clock this  afternoon and you can be paid today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they cheer their approval and return  to their buddies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Dickson starts back toward the offices,  Sampson comes to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't keep open till four o'clock.  We haven't cash enough to last an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think I know it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both start walking toward Dickson's  office - CAMERA TRUCKING WITH THEM.  As they pass the conference room, Schultz  comes out and stops Dickson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're still waiting for you, Dickson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson looks up, studies Schultz a  moment, as if trying to make up his  mind whether to consult the Board of  Directors or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Dickson enters, followed  by Schultz. They all look up. Dickson  goes up to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, gentlemen, we've got about one  more hour to go. You know what that  means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be forced to shut the doors. I've  worked twenty-five years night and day  to keep this bank alive. You've all  made money out of it. Are you willing  to help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that among you, you have at least  a million dollars in various banks throughout  the city. Get that money over here and  I'll stop this run within five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds very simple, Dickson, but  why should we jeopardize our personal  fortunes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have everything I own in it. It's  your bank as well as mine, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (this is just what he's been waiting  for)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, is it? Since when? Judging from  the way you've ignored us, you wouldn't  think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We tried to reason with you, but you  wouldn't listen to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The depositors you were protecting were  the first ones to pounce on you. You  thought they were your friends. Why  don't you go out there now and try and  get some help from them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, they've gone crazy. You can't reason  with a mob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You can't reason with anyone else  when you're in a jam. We pleaded with  you to keep liquid, but you wouldn't  listen to us. You preached to us about  faith and a lot of other rubbish. Now  you want our help. You want us to throw  a lot of cash into a bank that you've

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wrecked. All right. There's one way  you can get it. Give us an option on  your stock and resign as president.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, that's it, eh? You've waited a long  time for this chance, haven't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not going to resign now -  or ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking in the others at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't? I'll shut the bank first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't? You just wait and see. If that  run doesn't stop within the next hour,  I'll shut the doors. You know what that  means? The bank examiner will step in  tomorrow. You'll be forced to liquidate.  I'll insist upon it. The depositors  will be paid one hundred cents on the  dollar. What's left you gentlemen can  have. But I'll guarantee there won't  be enough to pay your next month's garage  bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With which ultimatum, he crosses to  the door and exits, CAMERA PANNING WITH  HIM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 192. INT. OUTSIDE CONFERENCE ROOM -  MED. CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Dickson barges out. He stops in front  of the door, and looks off toward lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 193. INT. LOBBY OF BANK - FULL SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pandemonium has broken loose. Men and  women are hysterical. The police battle  with recalcitrant depositors in a desperate  effort to maintain order. Strong men  push weak ones out of the lines. Wild-eyed  women jostle and scramble to get near  the paying tellers. Sex and priority  rights are totally disregarded. Above  it all the din is deafening. Men and  women are clamoring for their life's  savings, ready to commit murder to retrieve  their little stakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face clouds. As he stands there  watching the chaos, slowly the deep  concern vanishes from his face and his  jaw sets in grim determination. He starts  toward the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 195. ENTRANCE OF BANK - MED. CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cyril Cluett enters from outside, looking  guiltily around. Then he starts forward  and exits from scene. The moment he  is gone, Detective #3, who followed  him out, appears in the doorway and  crosses in the direction taken by Cluett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 196. OUTSIDE CONFERENCE ROOM - MEDIUM  CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get all the big bills in the place.  Take them out and get them changed.  Get nothing but ones and fives. Distribute  them among the tellers. Tell them to  take their time. Stall as much as possible.  Count and recount the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate to do this, but I've got to have  time to dig up some help. I think I  know where I can get some real cash.  Snap into it, Sampson. We will lick  this thing yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts out of scene towards his office.  CAMERA TRUCKS AFTER HIM, as he crosses  past Helen, talking without breaking  stride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on in here, Helen. Bring your book.  I want some numbers to try to get some  action. Get Parker at the Union-Leeds  - the Exchange . . . Winslow and old  man Harris at the Home Mortgage. Snap  into it, Helen. Just as quick as you  can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 197. INT. LOBBY OF BANK - FULL SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pandemonium, din and increasingly hysterical,  pushing crowds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 198. INT. CONFERENCE ROOM - MED. CLOSE  SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The directors apparently are having  a battle of their own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that mob. They're going crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, this run isn't doing the reputation  of this bank any good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much longer is Dickson going to  hold out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Dickson as well as we do. He'll  shut the doors before he gives up control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, let him! I'm sick and tired  of hearing about him. If he wants to  run the bank, let him do it. I don't  want any part of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 199. SOMEWHERE BACK OF TELLERS' CAGES  - MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One teller faces an angry depositor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly it's my signature. You've  seen it often enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but I'll have to verify it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 200. INT. DICKSON'S PRIVATE OFFICE -  CLOSE SHOT - DICKSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seated at his desk, talking into the  phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Parker. Listen. Listen, I've  got to have a million dollars in cash,  and I've got to have it quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no. Tomorrow is no good. I need  it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it's safe. Why, the bank's  in excellent condition. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector is making preparations  to take Matt down to headquarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better tell Mr. Dickson we're  taking Matt Brown downtown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Come on son. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The detective takes Matt's arm and makes  him get up from the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen rushes into the room and into  Matt's arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't cry, honey. Everything's gonna  be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The detective touches her shoulder,  tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen does not move. She clings to Matt,  sobbing violently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Detective #3 enters the room. CAMERA  PANS WITH HIM as he crosses to the Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you find out, Mike?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been trailing the cashier like  you told me. You're right about that  guy, chief. There's something screwy  somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind all that. What did you find  out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He left here about an hour ago and went  down to Dude Finlay's joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen slowly lifts her head from Matt's  shoulder. Her eyes widen as she hears  the name of Dude Finlay. Mike's voice  comes over this shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stayed about half an hour, and then  he came right back here. He's in his  office now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where I must have seen that guyВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Helen leaves Matt's side and crosses  to the Inspector and Mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was in the bank yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He came to see Mr. Cluett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he listens intently to Helen and  the Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two other men. They all went into Mr.  Cluett's private office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we're beginning to get somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking in all the people in the room.  The Inspector turns to the detective  and speaks quickly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelly! You stay here with Brown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim, you and Mike come with me. We're  going down to Cluett's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses to the door, followed by  Tim and Mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Inspector turns back and calls:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Kelly - call me up in Cluett's office  in about five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care what you say. Sing "Mother  Machree"[8] if you want to, but call  me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspector, Tim and Mike go out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 210. INT. LOBBY OF BANK - MEDIUM CLOSE  SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the elderly lady depositor and bank  guard, among the milling crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet down, please! Take it easy, folks.  Everything will be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you said it would be safe! It's  his life insurance money. Oh, please,  I'll go to the Old Ladies' Home if you  don't do something, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, lady. Please be quiet. Everything  will be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leading the old lady - pushing a path  through the crowd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open up here, folks. All right, folks,  please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 211. INT. DICKSON'S PRIVATE OFFICE -  CLOSE SHOT DICKSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seated at his desk, talking into the  phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good heavens, man, you're taking no  chances. No, I'm perfectly willing to  sign everything over to you. What more  do you want? I need action. I've got  to have it within the next half hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure - the board of directors  turned me down, but you know why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen. Listen, read it. It wouldn't  be a drop in the bucket to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. Uh-huh. All right - ask me for  a favor some time, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams the phone down angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 212. INT. CLUETT'S PRIVATE OFFICE -  MED. CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cluett sits at his desk. The Inspector  stands in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you don't mind me asking you  a few questions, Mr. Cluett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, yes. Just what would you  like to know, Inspector?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where were you at twelve o'clock last  night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very simple. I was home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is simple, isn't it? I assume you  can prove that if necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, of course. There was someone  with me. A lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like you're going to have no trouble  at all. What was the lady's name, Mr.  Cluett?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't mind, Inspector, I'd rather  not say - that is, unless it becomes  absolutely essential. You see, she's  married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The telephone rings at this point. Cluett  turns to answer it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the receiver. The Inspector  watches him closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cluett gets up out of his chair to permit  Inspector to get to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody must be in good humor. He was  humming "Mother Machree."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's one of the boys from headquarters.  He always sings "Mother Machree" whenever  he's got good news. Looks like this  case'll be settled in no time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face clouds at this. He listens  while Inspector's voice comes over scene:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Kelly? Huh? Dude Finlay! Where  do you got him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspector pauses, waiting for a reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective Kelly, speaking on the phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't got nobody here. I'm with Brown.  Didn't you tell me to call you up in  five minutes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cluett is terrified. The Inspector's  voice continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take him right down to headquarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cluett starts to edge out of scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector is still holding receiver  to his ear. Cluett has edged close to  the door, his expression one of desperation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector watches Cluett out of  the corner of his eye as he continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. What? . . . You don't mean Cyril  Cluett, the cashier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well! Did Dude Finlay tell you that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Dude Finlay? Sure, I got him here!  You know, for a minute I didn't catch  on . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. We got him here right now. Yeah,  yeah. Okay Kelly, good work. Looks likeВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He feels himself trapped. He glances  around the room quickly to determine  his chances to escape. He keeps edging  closer to the door with his back to  it. His hands sneaks down and grabs  hold of the doorknob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Cluett snaps open the door  and like a flash is out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Cluett's figure disappears. The detectives  are startled by the sudden move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The detectives dash out, Inspector following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 223. SOMEWHERE IN THE CROWDED OUTER  OFFICE - MED. CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 224. EXT. TO MEN'S LOCKER ROOM - MED.  CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the door of the men's locker room.  Cluett comes into scene and enters locker  room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 225. SOMEWHERE IN THE CROWDED OUTER  OFFICE - MEDIUM SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspector and detectives enter. Look  around quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They rush out of scene, their hands  on their guns, concealed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 226. INT. MEN'S LOCKER ROOM - FULL SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Metal lockers line the entire room.  Cluett comes to door on other side of  the room. Just as he gets there, he  hears the detectives entering off scene.  Quickly he changes his mind and springs  into a space between a row of lockers  and the wall, at the same time drawing  his gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspector and detectives enter. The  Inspector and one of the detectives  advance into the room cautiously, holding  their guns in front of them. Kelley,  the other detective, shrewdly separates  from them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must be here. There's only one door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cluett slips into a locker and closes  the door behind him. They hear the noise  off scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A locker, eh? Well, search every one  of them. He must be in one of 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They search the lockers one by one,  until the Inspector happens upon the  one with Cluett inside. He leaps out,  gun drawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand back Inspector, or I'll shoot.  Drop that gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The detective and Inspector. The detective  drops his gun, but the Inspector keeps  his levelled, toward Cluett, off scene:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be a fool, Cluett. This is only  going to make it worse for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand back, Inspector. Let me out of  here, or I'll shoot you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector ignores the warning. He  takes a few more steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I warn you, Inspector - I'll shoot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts his gun and aims for Cluett,  off scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is frightened, but desperate. He  has his finger on the trigger, ready  to fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you take another step, I'llВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shot is heard. The gun drops out of  Cluett's hand. His arm goes limp. His  face screws up in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rushing forward to grab him - to the  detectives)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see it! Let me see it! It's only  his finger. Get me a towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now take it easy, buddy. Take it easy.  All we want to do is talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 232. INT. A TELLER'S CAGE MED. - CLOSE  SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People standing in line, an atmosphere  of pandemonium and hysteria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 233. INT. DICKSON'S PRIVATE OFFICE -  CLOSE SHOT - DICKSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still at phone. His coat is now off  and flung across the desk. His face  is worn. Perspiration rolls down his  face. His appearance indicates he has  been on the phone a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't do a thing. You're up to your  neck. All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He listens. He is being turned down.  He hangs up receiver. Over his face  slowly comes a look of deep perturbation.  He refers to a small notebook open on  his desk. His finger runs down the list  of names as he searches for another  prospect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS ACROSS as Inspector and  other detectives, with Cluett in custody,  enter Dickson's office, all excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were right, Mr. Dickson! Brown didn't  have anything to do with it. Here's  your man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, you must be crazy. I've known this  man for years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's just confessed. He's been mixed  up with the toughest gangsters in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS BACK to Dickson, as he stares,  unbelievingly, at the shrunken figure  of Cluett, who is trembling with fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Confessed! Cluett, in heaven's name,  what got into you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. It's all been like a crazy  nightmare, Mr. Dickson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened? You're not a thief. How'd  you get mixed up with these kind of  people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gambling - I owed them a lot of money.  Last week I lost over fifty thousand  dollars!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I didn't kill that man last night.  Honest I didn't, Mr. Dickson!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday they came to collect it. I  begged them to wait. I wanted time to  think, but they wouldn't listen to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They threatened to kill me if I didn't  pay it! I was desperate! I didn't know  what to do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he reacts to Cluett's confession.  Cluett's voice continues over this shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then they suggested that I help them  rob the bank. All I had to do was turn  off the alarm and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: fix the time clock. It all sounded so  easy. It seemed like a way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know anybody was going to be  killed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you doing at Finlay's this  morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They took my keys yesterday. I went  there to get them back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you were in a jam, why didn't you  come to me? I would have helped you  out. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was crazy, I tell you, Mr. Dickson.  I didn't know what I was doing. I wandered  around in a daze. All I could think  of was that they were going to kill  me . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll stand by me, won't you, Mr. Dickson?  You won't go back on me now, will you?  I'll die if they send me to prison!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget there's a dead watchman  downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't kill him! I had nothing to  do with that, I tell you! I was home  in my apartment last night - I can prove  it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claims he was there with a married woman.  Doesn't want to mention her name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't believe it, Mr. Dickson. But  it's the truth - honest it is. I was  in my apartment last night - ask your  wife - sheВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops dead. Suddenly he realizes  what he is saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he reacts electrically to the mention  of his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slaps a hand over his mouth, as if  to crush out anything further he might  say. He stares wide-eyed and frightened  at Dickson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 242. CLOSE TWO SHOT - DICKSON AND CLUETT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson glares at Cluett, penetratingly.  His brain slowly absorbs the revelation  that Phyllis was in Cluett's apartment  the night before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife? What's she got to do with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out of the side of his mouth - to a  detective standing next to him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No wonder he didn't want to mention  her name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson comes over to Cluett, grabs  him by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was my wife doing in your apartment  last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, nothing, Mr. Dickson. Don't  pay any attention to me. I don't know  what I'm saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just mentioned her name. What was  she doing there? What was she doing  in your apartment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just came up for a drink. Just for  a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson grabs Cluett and shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Mr. Dickson. We'll find  out whether he's telling the truth.  I'll have a man from headquarters check  up on it right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to check up on anybody.  I'll do all the checking up. Wait a  minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS WITH HIM as he crosses to  his desk, and calls Helen on the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get Mrs. Dickson on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an awkward pause while Dickson  waits. He is obviously agitated. Then  the phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, dear. I want to ask you something.  I know it's a silly thing for me to  ask you, but . . . I want you to tell  me the truth. Where were you last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 244. INT. DICKSON HOME - CLOSEUP - MRS.  DICKSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night? Er - why - uh, last night  . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, dear. Now tell me the truth  about this. Were you in Cluett's apartment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 246. INT. DICKSON HOME - CLOSEUP - MRS.  DICKSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Cluett's apartment? Well dear, you  see, I . . . I . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 247. INT. DICKSON'S OFFICE - MED. CLOSE  SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Favoring Dickson, but showing Cluett  and the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson slowly puts the phone receiver  down. His face is ashen. He is shaken  to the core.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wasn't to blame, Mr. Dickson. It  wasn't her fault. Honest, it wasn't.  I begged her to come up. She didn'tВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The detectives get on either side of  Cluett and silently they march him out  of the room. Inspector and others follow,  leaving Dickson alone. When they have  gone out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Left alone, he is a tragic figure. An  incessant parade of disturbing thoughts  tumble over each other in a hectic march  across his chaotic mind. He grips his  throbbing temples in an effort to crush  out the torturous thought that Phyllis  was involved in an intrigue with Cyril  Cluett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the directors seem to be weakening.  O'Brien is remaining staunch to Dickson.  Clark alone, holds out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark, you're insane to hold out any  longer. Now let's get some money over  here and stop this run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we close our doors, our stock won't  be worth a nickel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meek little Ives once more tries to  speak:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll lay you ten to one, Dickson won't  give in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Featuring Schultz and Clark, standing  together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'll go and have a talk with  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he starts to walk toward the door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 251. INT. DICKSON'S PRIVATE OFFICE -  FULL SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson sits at his desk, his head cupped  in his hands. Clark enters thru door  of outer office, quietly. He looks at  Dickson a moment, then crosses to the  desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson slowly looks up at Clark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson, I'd like to talk to you about  the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bank. All right. Do anything you  want with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face lights up. This is a turn he  never expected. He really came in to  capitulate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll draw up the option on your stock  - say, eighty dollars a share. How's  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is not even interested, speaks vaguely:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eighty dollars? That's fine - anything  you say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, good. I'll draw it up at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Clark starts out of Dickson's office,  elated, Helen comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want the rest of those numbers,  Mr. Dickson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares at him, surprised, backs  out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 256. INT. OUTER ROOM OF DICKSON'S OFFICE  - HELEN AND MATT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he doing, honey? Is he getting  any help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's happened. He isn't trying  anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They must have turned him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. He called some of the biggest people  in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, they'd turn him down. He ought  to know that. I'm going in there and  talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS ACROSS as Matt enters:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't got much time left, Mr. Dickson.  We've got to do something quick or it'll  be too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why wouldn't you tell me where you were  last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not giving up, are you, Mr. Dickson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I can explain about that later.  You're losing your bank - don't you  realize what that means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Mr. Dickson, don't let them  lick you just because a couple of big  shots turned you down. You've got more  friends than anybody in this town. Little  guys - guys who wouldn't be in business  if it weren't for you. All you've got  to do isВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Answer my question. Was  Mrs. Dickson there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was, wasn't she? How long has this  been going on? Do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, I don't know what you're talking  about. All I know is that you're losing  your bank andВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 258. INT. DICKSON'S OUTER OFFICE - MATT  AND HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got an idea. Come on, let's get to  a telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 259. INT. DICKSON'S PRIVATE OFFICE -  MED. CLOSEUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of his beliefs are shaken by this  seeming betrayal. Dickson takes a framed  photograph of Phyllis from his desk,  gingerly sets it face down in the center  drawer of his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also in the desk drawer is - he cannot  help but notice - a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 260. INT. CONFERENCE ROOM - CLOSE SHOT  - CLARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he dictates to someone off screen:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—a thirty-day option on ten thousand  shares of stock of this company, now  registered in the name of Thomas A.  Dickson. Now make that in triplicate  and get it to me just as fast as you  can. Hurry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 261. INT. SOMEWHERE IN THE BANK - CLOSE  SHOT AT PAYROLL WINDOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting past cashier in f.g. towards  line of laborers waiting to be paid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cashier stands in front of a tall counter  upon which is a small metal box filled  with currency. He is speaking into the  phone by his side as scene opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up receiver and turns to the  men on the other side of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry ladies and gentlemen, there's  no more money. You'll have to go on  to the next window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He snaps the window shut, slams down  cover of little metal box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angry ad-lib from line of laborers waiting  to be paid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean there's no more money?  etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panicked shouting and pushing. In the  center of the crowd, a woman faints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another cashier, another window, another  angry line of depositors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 262. INT. DICKSON'S OUTER OFFICE - MEDIUM  CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis Dickson, serious-faced, comes  up steps and thru ante room on the way  to Dickson's private office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pounds on door of office. There  is no reply from within. Standing next  to her is a bank guard, uncertain about  what to do. Throughout scene, there  are b.g. sounds of melee in the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure he's in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. He must be in there. He  hasn't come out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pounds on the door again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to get in there. Can't you  find me a key?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I think there's one right here  in the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 263. INT. DICKSON'S PRIVATE OFFICE -  FULL SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson is standing by a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks over to him - CAMERA PANNING  WITH HER - and stands in back of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom! Oh Tom, darling - I came to explain  about last night . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson remains silent. Mrs. Dickson  continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cyril Cluett doesn't mean anything to  me, Tom. I went out with him last night  simply because . . . well, I had begun  to feel that I didn't have any part  in your life. That I was an outsider.  Tom, all we did was to go to the theatre,  and then we went back to his apartment  afterward for a drink. That's all it  was. I didn't do anything wrong, Tom.  I couldn't do anything wrong. I love  you too much. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he stares dully out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Dickson's voice coming over shot:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 266. INT. SOMEWHERE IN BANK - MEDIUM  CLOSE SHOT - MATT AND HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are furiously working two phones,  going down a list of people who owe  Dickson and the bank a favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although Matt has focus in the scene,  Helen's voice is always in b.g., as  she handles calls, making the same pitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson's in a jam I tell you. The run's  getting worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big guys have got the screws on  him. You've got to come through for  him, Mr. Conway. He came through for  you a hundred times. If his friends  don't help him, who is going to help  him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up from her own phone pitch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 267. INT. LOBBY OF BANK - MED. SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a man elbows his way thru the crowd  to a receiving teller's window. He is  accompanied by a bank guard, who sweeps  the disbelieving crowd aside. He speaks  loudly for everyone's benefit:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any bank that Tom Dickson has anything  to do with is all right. I'm putting  my money in here. Why should you be  afraid? Give him a chance. Tom Dickson  is all right! He's perfectly square.  I'm putting my money in this bank! I  know what I'm doing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches a teller's window, which  is closed. He pounds on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open up! I want to put some money in  here! I don't want to take any out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A teller's face appears, somewhat astonished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 268. INT. SOMEWHERE IN BANK - MED. CLOSE  SHOT - MATT AND HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're starting to come in already.  Yeah. Yeah. Well, listen. Don't waste  any time. Get all the money you can  lay your hands on, and bring it down  here right away. Step on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen has dialed another prospect also,  and hands the phone to Matt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll talk to both of them at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding both phones up to his mouth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, both you fellows. Dickson's  in a jam. The run's getting worse. Those  big guys got the screws on him. Yeah,  both you fellows got to come thru for  him. Listen, if his friends don't help  him, who is going to help him? Now he  came through for you a hundred times.  Yeah, listen. They're starting to come  in already. Yeah, listen. Both of you  fellas - get all the money you can lay  your hands on, and bring it down here  right away. Both of you - step on it!  All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 269. INT. LOBBY OF BANK - MED. SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As several more people elbow their way  thru the crowd on their way to teller's  windows, speaking aloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of my way. I got money I want  to put into the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS WITH HIM and second man  until they reach the receiving teller's  window, where they fall into a line  already containing ten or twelve people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second man shoves his way to the  front, and addresses the teller:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to make a deposit. Four thousand,  six hundred dollars. He's the best man  in the world. I believe in him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 270. INT. DICKSON'S PRIVATE OFFICE -  CLOSE TWO SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson and Phyllis Dickson. She is  still explaining to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter what you think about  me, there's something far more important.  Those people down there. The bank, Tom.  You can't give that up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is interrupted by sound of door  opening. They look off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Sampson steps in. He looks off toward  Dickson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Dickson! Come here a minute. Look  at this. Something wonderful has happened.  People are bringing deposits. You won't  believe it until you see it. You have  to come out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson and Mrs. Dickson. He shambles  over towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 273. INT. OUTSIDE OF DICKSON'S OFFICE  - MED. CLOSE SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Sampson and Dickson come out from  private office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson gazes in the direction he points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The line has grown in size. Those trying  to deposit their money are just as excited  as those who want to draw it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Dickson is a friend of mine! I'll  put money in his bank any time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody who takes money out of this  bank is crazy! I'm going to put a lot  of money in! Here it is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't got much, but here it is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Dickson can have all my money any  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 275. INT. OUTSIDE OF DICKSON'S OFFICE  - CLOSEUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Dickson, looking toward Receiving  Teller's window. He stares at the miraculous  spectacle, deeply moved. He can scarcely  believe his own eyes. A smile grows  on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sight of his friends coming to his  rescue has an electrical effect on Dickson.  It revives his fighting spirit. He sticks  his jaw out determinedly. Without a  word he turns and crosses to door of  conference room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson flings the door open. Clark  and the other directors are startled  out of their business. Clark holds the  necessary transfer papers in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come out here you pawnbrokers - take  a look at this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what you can do with that!  Come on, take a look at this! You'll  see a demonstration of faith that's  worth more than all the collateral in  the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While he has been speaking, several  of the directors have edged over to  the door. They are perceptibly impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has remained unmoved, staring at  Dickson, as if trying to determine what  kind of ruse is this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on boys! Come on Clark! It'll do  your heart good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS WITH CLARK, as he crosses  slowly to the door and looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that. They're shoving their  hard-earned money across the counter  with a ten to one chance against them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they edge out onto balcony overlooking  scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you fellas want to save this bank,  get some real money over here right  away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough for me, Dickson. I'm ashamed  of myself. I'll have a hundred thousand  dollars over here in five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O'Brien starts away and crosses to a  phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your bank, Dickson, and I'm  with you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At last he can say something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear friends, that's what I've been  trying to say all afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark, you can do twice as much as any  of them. How about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't agree with you, but if everybody's  gone crazy, I'll go crazy too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 281. INT. CONFERENCE ROOM - SERIES OF  CLOSEUPS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Clark and the other directors make  their urgent phone calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Ben Schultz talking. Send a  hundred thousand cash over here to the  Union National right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send all your available cash to Union  National!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, I want one hundred and fifty thousand  dollars over here right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am in my right mind. No, no, no. Not  one hundred and fifty dollars. Say,  listen you guys, one hundred and fifty  thousand dollars. Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A string of armored cars speed toward  camera, accompanied by an escort of  eight motorcycle cops. The procession  heralds its approach by the piercing  wail of sirens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dozen policemen precede the entrance  of a parade of uniformed guards, who  carry in one hand sacks of money, their  other hands clasped firmly on their  guns. The crowd in the lobby stands  aside, awe-stricken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murmurs of approval are heard from the  crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 284. INT. BANK NEAR FRONT DOOR - MED.  SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the crowd is leaving the bank. Everyone  is smiling and happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the trouble with people nowadays.  They hear a crazy rumor, and right away  they lose their heads. Not me! You didn't  see me drawing my money out, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she works the switchboard - the next  day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning. Union National Bank. Just  a minute . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 286. INT. BANK VAULT - MEDIUM SHOT -  GROUP OF TELLERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they gather for their morning ritual,  waiting for Matt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine o'clock and all is lousy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten to one he'll have a crack about  the run yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a cinch bet. I wouldn't take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he pulls a gag about the run, we'll  murder the guy. Murder him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hear Matt approaching, and gesture  silence. Matt strides purposefully in.  He works the mechanism on the vault.  There is a long silence, during which  nobody says anything, most surprisingly  of all, not even Matt. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after having opened the lock - turning  to the group of expectant tellers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I suppose you guys had a good  run for your money yesterday!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They tackle him to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 287. INT. BANK ENTRANCE MED. - CLOSE  SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Dickson enters, and playfully pushes  the hat down over Gardiner, the old  bank guard's face. The bank guard adjusts  his hat, annoyed, then sees it is the  president of the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Dickson. My wife is  much better this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's too bad. Mine's all right  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guard puzzles over his non-sequitur  for a moment, then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA TRUCKS AHEAD OF DICKSON, as he  strides through the lobby, passing various  individuals from opening scenes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spots the teller with a habit of  smoking on the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The teller, from Dickson's angle, holds  up his empty hands. No cigarettes. Then,  he opens his mouth and chews elaborately,  showing that he has switched to gum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hellos and Good Mornings greet Dickson  as he continues on his way. He passes  the janitor in a new uniform, and stops  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well, well - got your uniform,  eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks good. How much did it cost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Mr. Sampson bought it  for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickson opens his jacket, affects an  unenthusiastic perusal of his own well-worn  suit of clothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh-oh. I guess I'll have to see Sampson  myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS HIM as he approaches  Helen's desk outside his own private  office. Helen looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, I know what's the matter with you.  Matt!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt, hearing his name, dashes up to  stand next to Dickson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you both to take the day off.  Go downtown and get a license and get  married right away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hear any more about  it. If you don't get married, I'll fire  both of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now they are beaming. Dickson starts  off, then has a second thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen, while you're downtown, you might  stop in and make reservations for the  bridal suite on the Berengaria[9] sailing  next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no! It's not for you. You're only  going to get married. Mrs. Dickson and  I are going to go on the honeymoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With just the barest suggestion of a  wink, he exits.
